titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the E. Dorrit Hoffleit Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Carol King; William R. Massa, Jr.; and William Landis

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:17

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The materials consist primarily of research notes; materials for presentations and articles; correspondence; photographs; biographical materials, and printed ephemera documenting the career of E. Dorrit Hoffleit in the field of astronomy.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Astronomy Department, Yale University, 2008. Materials were removed from Hoffleit's office by the Astronomy Department following her death.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: E. Dorrit Hoffleit Papers (MS 1915). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ellen Dorrit Hoffleit was born in Florence, Alabama, on March 12, 1907. She received a B.A. in mathematics (1928) and a Ph.D. in astronomy (1938) from Radcliffe College; and a D.Sc. from Smith College (1984) and from Central Connecticut State University (1998). Hoffleit was a research assistant at the Harvard College Observatory in 1929 and was hired as an astronomer at Harvard in 1948. In 1943, she joined the Ballistic Research Laboratory at Aberdeen Proving Ground to compute missile trajectories. Hoffleit left Harvard in 1956 to run Yale University's star cataloging program. She authored the Bright Star Catalogue , containing information on the 9,110 brightest stars, and co-authored the General Catalogue of Trigonometric Stellar Parallaxes , containing precise distance measurements to 8,112 stars. She retired from Yale in 1975. Hoffleit was also director of the Maria Mitchell Observatory, Nantucket, from 1957 to 1978. In 1988, minor planet 3416 was named "Dorrit"in her honor. Hoffleit died at her New Haven, Connecticut, apartment on April 9, 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials consist primarily of research notes; materials for presentations and articles; correspondence; photographs; biographical materials, and printed ephemera documenting the career of E. Dorrit Hoffleit in the field of astronomy.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as received from the Astronomy Department, Yale University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files include correspondence, printed ephemera, clippings, and writings.

scopecontent.p: Includes photographs and biographical information, primarily about Yale and Harvard astronomers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs, biographical information, correspondence, and drafts of writings, primarily about Yale and Harvard astronomers and women in astronomy.

scopecontent.p: Includes primarily family and professional photographs.
